I realise many people complained about the pouches when we introduced them last year. Four hundred and sixty-two schools have now drawn down the money. One teacher said to me that the children can be heard again in the corridors. I was shocked. In other words, the children are shouting and roaring in the corridors again.

No one should have a mobile phone at a meeting. I am serious. I bring no mobile phone with me to meetings. I am not referring to any Member present. I bring no mobile phone to Cabinet meetings. If you have a mobile phone, you are not concentrating, focusing on the issues or listening to your colleagues articulating points. We provided the pouches in schools.
We are moving on.

Have I answered every question? There was one on interagency work. Interagency work is key. The Cabinet subcommittee system is a mechanism. It is hard going and there are many subcommittees, but they bring people together. We had Tusla before the Cabinet subcommittee on children recently. It was very effective, and we got a very good insight into the work of Tusla and its challenges.

I thank the Taoiseach. We are now moving on to Deputy Erin McGreehan, who is Chair of the Joint Committee on Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science, Deputy Conor McGuinness, who is Chair of the Joint Committee on Fisheries and Maritime Affairs, and Deputy Malcolm Byrne, who is Chair of the Joint Committee on Artificial Intelligence. They have two minutes each and will be taken in the sequence in which I have mentioned them.

I thank the Taoiseach very much for being here. The priorities of the Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science are central to Ireland's long-term economic strength, social mobility and innovation capacity. As we all know, they shape the opportunities available to our learners, researchers and workers across the entire country. Looking ahead, we need a system that is responsive, more ambitious, more flexible, more inclusive and capable of delivering the talent and research ecosystem required in a modern country and the growing economy we demand. Considering the global economic turbulence, there are gaps domestically. We need considerable funding ambition in the Department. Areas of significant importance are access and capacity within the system, the substantial expansion of places, and research and innovation.
We need to significantly scale up the national research fund and innovation hubs, etc.

I raise skills and the workforce. There are acute shortages in healthcare, construction, digital technology and green skills. Inclusion, disability and mental health supports are persistent barriers to education. We need to invest in infrastructure, including campus development and student accommodation. Apprenticeships need a huge increase in investment. I also raise the shared island unit and the huge role it can have, particularly in Dundalk, with the development of the first all-Ireland university with linkage between Queen's University Belfast and DkIT. I am ambitious for this and I look forward to seeing how the shared island unit can invest in Louth.

I will run through three of the biggest items that the fisheries and maritime affairs committee has been dealing with over the past number of months. The first will come as no surprise to the Taoiseach today. The December Council begins and the fisheries quota negotiations for next year are under way. The entire committee and I were adamant that these negotiations needed a whole-of-government approach. We have said as much to the Minister of State, Deputy Dooley on several occasions. The industry is in freefall. The Taoiseach met with fishing industry representatives fairly recently. These negotiations are make or break for the fishing industry in Ireland and for our coastal communities. What we need is the Taoiseach as the Head of Government to play a role in these negotiations. A Minister is going over there against larger countries with larger fishing interests with senior Ministers around the table. Negotiating in a silo is not going to cut it to extract the concessions, the Hague preferences and the additional quota that we need. We need the Taoiseach as the head of Government and a whole-of-government approach. What will the Taoiseach be doing today and tomorrow to assist in those negotiations?

The Sea-Fisheries Protection Authority, SFPA, was before the committee recently. It was utterly unsatisfactory in how it engaged with the committee. The SFPA is part of a wider piece of work that we are doing on sea fisheries protection more broadly. My colleague Deputy Pádraig Mac Lochlainn is rapporteur on that. I do not want to pre-empt his recommendations in that report that he will bring before the committee early in the new year, but picking up the mood of the committee members and my own assessment is that there is a deficit when it comes to accountability and transparency from that particular agency. That will necessitate legislative change. I would like the Taoiseach to look at that and to be supportive of those committee recommendations when they do come in the new year and to legislative.

He mentioned offshore renewable energy in his opening statement. What will he do to ensure codesign is at the very core of how offshore renewable energy is developed and that rather than going down the extractive and exploitative model of energy generation off our coast, we have one that benefits coastal communities and ensures that coastal communities that bear the greatest impact of this infrastructure and development get the greatest dividend?

I thank the Taoiseach for being with us today. The Joint Committee on Artificial Intelligence is grateful for the support of our secretariat and to the Minister of State, Deputy Niamh Smyth and her officials. We will issue a short report next week, which will make a number of recommendations about how the Government should support the use of AI responsibly but about how the Government itself should adapt and integrate it into government processes to deliver public services more effectively and efficiently. It is critical that we get the right balance between regulation and innovation. What is important in terms of our asks of the Taoiseach is to continue to provide leadership in this space, that the AI office, which will be established next year, will not be a thou shalt not office but one that will be facilitative and support SMEs and civic society organisations to meet their obligations under the AI Act, but also to ensure that Ireland becomes a leader in the adoption of AI in a safe way.

Our committee is also going to support the setting up of an AI observatory, which has a lot of supports, which is an evidence-based, research-led institution that will examine the potential impact of AI on aspects of society and the economy and ensuring that where there is displacement in employment we upskill and reskill. We are aware that the Minister, Deputy Lawless is going to be bringing a number of proposals in that regard. We think it is critical that there is investment in upskilling and reskilling. As part of the EU Presidency, we want to ensure that Ireland positions itself as an AI leader but that in Europe's competitiveness agenda using technology and AI is a key part of that. We welcome the commitment to the AI summit that will be held by the Government in October. We hope that the Taoiseach will attend. We would like to hope that as many heads of Government would be able to attend at the summit as well.

I will respond to Deputy McGreehan first. The third and fourth level sectors are central to economic development in this country. It is one of the reasons I initiated the establishment of the Department of higher education in 2020. It has the capacity to underpin future innovation and economic development. Research is key. The INSPIRE programme that the Minister, Deputy Lawless has announced recently represents the step change that I wanted this Department to engage in in the research space. It builds on the PRTLI model of an earlier period in the late 1990s and early 2000s. It will be critical in building a research infrastructure in universities. Universities are adapting a whole range of skills. The Deputy referred to green skills. There are also mental health supports within campuses. I am quite impressed with some campuses where there are better spaces, in terms of people who need to take time out of the hustle and bustle and all the noise and so on. We always need to watch the mental health supports in universities and further education that they are there for the students on an ongoing basis.

On the situation in the shared island, the Queen's University and Dundalk initiative is a significant development. It is important for Dundalk because it was not part of others in the technological university sector. Here is an opportunity now for both colleges to get together and go through governance frameworks and all the necessary work that has to be done. The shared island unit stands ready to support that initiative and to be supportive of it. It is important to get the framework right and all of that. This is a great opportunity. I know the Deputy has been passionately advocating for this. We will take that on board.

Deputy McGuinness spoke about fisheries. It is a core issue. I met with the group. To be frank, I engage with the Commission on a whole range of issues. We have to maintain a constructive relationship with the Commission. I have spoken to President von der Leyen in respect of the derogation on nitrates and the entirety of issues in agriculture. We will have to engage with the Commission on fishing. ICES research is saying it is overfished not by us, but by others that the European Union engages with. Non-EU countries are overfishing the entire area. It will mean a 70% reduction in the pelagic catch. That is on top of a 20% reduction as a result of Brexit. This is existential for the industry. We are going to have to go back to the Commission in respect of whatever supports we want to give from our Exchequer, which, at the moment, would have to take on board state aid rules, which I understand from talking to officials are quite restrictive in respect of what states can do. Given the exceptional nature of what is hitting the industry, we are going to have to be innovative and responsive.

The Minister of State, Deputy Dooley, and the Minister, Deputy Heydon, are negotiating now in terms of the Fisheries Council. It is beyond that in terms of the scale and impact. I take the Deputy's point. I am aware of that. Deputy Pat the Cope Gallagher and all the Deputies in Donegal, west Cork and coastal communities more generally are concerned about this because the impact on those communities will be significant. There are large concentrations of employment in Donegal, Castletownbere, Waterford, Wexford and so forth. We will await the outcome in terms of what the committee is proposing in respect of the authorities on transparency and all of that.

On offshore, the Deputy can use the terms exploitative or extractive, but we need offshore renewable energy. Coastal communities should benefit and there should be a dividend for them. We have to go for it. If we do not, we are in real trouble energy-wise, climate-wise and everything else.

Deputy Malcolm Byrne referenced AI, which connects in to the offshore issue. Our commitment to AI and our capacity to adopt AI will be dependent on having sufficient energy resources because AI is energy intensive. In terms of large energy users, future foreign direct investment will be critical. Regarding the Deputy's point on Government public services, we look forward to his committee's recommendations. I agree with his first-class idea around AI observatories. What we need to do, very quickly, is monitor the employment patterns because already there are signs that it is beginning to manifest itself in some parts of the economy. We need real-time monitoring of what is happening in terms of AI's impact on the jobs market. An interesting report we got from the expert group on future skills needs indicates that Ireland is actually very high on skill levels and our AI competency per capita is one of the highest across Europe but we need to build on that. That is a good news story but areas like energy are less so.

Public service adoption of AI is critical, as the Deputy said. We are working on enhancing digital public services and supporting enterprises to accelerate their use of digital technologies. There is a whole programme on digital public services aimed at 100% digitisation of key public services and driving responsible AI adoption across the public sector. The Minister for Public Expenditure, Infrastructure, Public Service Reform and Digitalisation, Deputy Chambers, has a significant programme in that area, again related to productivity gains within the public sector and better delivery of public services. We want to be a location of choice for ethical AI and digital start-ups and a global hub for innovation.

I take the Deputy's point about the balance between regulation and innovation and that is something we have to work very hard on. The perception is that in Europe the balance is on the regulatory side as opposed to the innovative side. The Commission is trying to correct that with its investment announcements in respect of AI factories and so on. We are trying to piggy-back onto that and be part of that process. It is a transformative area, of that there is no doubt. There will be bumps along the way and highs and lows in respect of this but there is no doubt that the technology will improve, refine and develop. We cannot just put our heads in the sand. We cannot put our heads in the sand in relation to data centres either. We have issues now in terms of energy but data centres are not the great evil. They are a reality of modern life and modern societies and economies globally. That is just a reality but there are limits to what the grid can do at any one time. That is why the offshore wind revolution has to happen. Ireland is probably one of the leaders in integrating renewables onto the grid because of our experience in onshore wind and because of our work in solar. The Oireachtas needs to grapple with this too. When I am in the Dáil, I hear comments about that wind farm, that gas station or that anaerobic digestion facility but equally, we have a more national problem of how to replace fossil fuels with renewables. It is a real challenge for everybody because we must have energy to run the country and to maintain people's high-quality livelihoods.
I have said enough, I apologise. I thought that was the last foray but I see Deputy Gannon lurking menacingly.

There are three final questioners but the Taoiseach only has ten more minutes because he has another commitment. Deputy Conway-Walsh, Chair of the Joint Committee on Defence and National Security is next, followed by Deputy Gannon, Chair of the drugs use committee and then Senator Mark Daly, Cathaoirleach of the Seanad Select Committee on EU Scrutiny and Transparency and each contributor has two minutes.

I assure the Taoiseach that we have plenty of energy on the defence and national security committee. This morning we spent time out at the National Cyber Security Centre and I want to acknowledge the great work being done there and thank the centre for hosting us this morning. I welcome the increased funding to address the decades of neglect of our Defence Forces. Oireachtas oversight of national security has never been more urgently needed, especially with Ireland's upcoming EU Presidency and the pending national security strategy. We are lucky that we have an excellent committee comprised of members, both Government and non-Government, with huge experience within the Defence Forces and they take their responsibilities really seriously. Following efforts to examine areas within national security policy, the committee has found that its current remit does not allow proper examination of this policy area. The key stakeholders in the area of national security such as the Taoiseach's Department and An Garda Síochána have both declined invitations to attend meetings of the committee on the basis that its remit does not extend to aspects of national security policy under the control of the committee.

At recent meetings the committee agreed to draft a request to the committee on procedure to seek an extension of its remit to fully cover national security. The committee has found that under its current narrow remit in relation to national security it cannot provide oversight and adequately examine this critical policy area which is included in the committee's name. The committee is seeking to have its remit extended to cover all aspects of national security. As per Dáil Éireann Standing Order 109(3), the committee has reviewed its procedures and its role and is making the request in this context. The committee also notes that other sectoral committees, such as the Joint Committee on Fisheries and Maritime Affairs, have a remit which covers aspects of more than one Department. The committee considers that given that national security is in its title, its remit should extend to all aspects of oversight in the area and not just those under the Department of Defence. I am sure the Taoiseach understands what I am saying and I ask him to have a look at this issue in the context of the geopolitical turbulence and challenges that we are all facing. He said he was very much in favour of protecting the fundamentals of parliamentary democracy and in that vein, I ask him to look at the remit of the defence and national security committee and to enable us to do the job that needs to be done.

I thank the Taoiseach for joining us today. I chair the Joint Committee on Drugs Use. It was formed following the Citizen's Assembly on Drug Use, which was chaired by Mr. Paul Reid. That assembly engaged in the most comprehensive analysis and exploration of drug use in the history of this State. Our committee has a nine-month duration and is putting flesh on the bones of the work of the citizen's assembly. Our committee will report in June but the national drugs strategy is due to be released in draft form in January. We have talked to the Minister of State with responsibility in this area, Deputy Murnane O'Connor, who has agreed to more engagement with the committee in terms of its input to the strategy. I wanted to reference that with the Taoiseach and put it on the record.

One of the issues that we are currently dealing with that is incredibly important is drug-related intimidation, violence and coercion. There are very few communities the length and breadth of Ireland that have not been affected in some form by drug-related intimidation. We saw that in its most hideous, extreme and tragic form last weekend in County Offaly and it is something that all of us must work to confront. These gangs are enforcing intimidation and violence on communities. The stories that we have heard at the committee from the communities that are engaging with us are terrifying, they are real and they require an immediate response.

I thank the Taoiseach for being here. I also thank him and Mr. Diarmuid Lynch for their support for the establishment of the EU scrutiny committee back in 2022. The Cabinet made the decision on 12 July that year to establish the committee, which goes to the point he made about gold-plated EU rules and regulations and the examination of those. That committee's original title was the committee for the scrutiny of EU-related draft statutory instruments but we have tightened it up and it is now the committee on EU scrutiny and transparency. The work of the committee includes getting the draft statutory instruments before the Minister signs them and making sure they are passed on to the relevant sectoral committees to give them an opportunity to scrutinise them in advance of them being signed. It also includes examining issues that would affect us in relation to the Windsor Framework or the impact of EU proposals on legislation that would impact our relationship with our big trading partners such the UK, EU, US and Canada. It also includes the big issue of fines. I will give the Taoiseach an example. This is the directive that came in on organ donation. It is 16 pages long. By the time the Department of Health was finished adding to it, the document was 36 pages long. It had to be amended subsequently because it was so badly drafted.

That was highlighted by the Irish Kidney Association. Another six pages were added so 42 pages of legislation never went to the health committee and it was the first ever legislation on organ donation in the history of the State. Health committee TDs and Senators never saw it.

The other issue we look at is that of fines. Most recently, we paid a fine of €1.5 million for the late transposition or adoption of the legislation on work-life balance. The last time, the committee - and this is the ask - only got five draft Bills out of a few hundred. So far, we have only received one. The committee is meeting next week in the Seanad Chamber. I will write to the Taoiseach and the committee will write to Departments to ask them to comply with the Cabinet decision that we get the draft statutory instruments - not just us, but that we would be able to pass them on to the various sectoral committees to give them an opportunity to scrutinise them in advance. That is, first, so we do not incur fines but, second, that democratic oversight actually takes place when it comes to what about amounts to more legislation than what the Dáil actually passes.
Can the Taoiseach respond to those? I am conscious that he has be somewhere in five minutes.

I appreciate the comments Deputy Conway-Walsh made. The Oireachtas sets the criteria; I think the Deputy has now referred it to the procedural committee. I will reflect on what she said. This is a first in regard to national security. We have not had a culture in the Oireachtas for dealing with national security issues like other parliaments historically have. We have to be conscious of confidentiality requirements in respect of what can be revealed at any given public meeting in respect of security. It could create unintended vulnerabilities.
I completely understand that-----

The Deputy might let me finish. I will certainly reflect on it and I would be interested in what the procedural committee's view on it is as well. There would have to be responses from what at the moment would be the Department of Defence. It should be responding to the Deputy.
It is.

It is. Fair enough. I am glad the Deputy was at the National Cyber Security Centre. It is a very good centre and we have made huge progress in respect of cybersecurity in the past five years. I will reflect on what she said and come back to her in the context of her desires and that of the committee to broaden its remit.

Deputy Gannon spoke about drug use. I will talk to the Minister of State, Deputy Murnane O'Connor, on what he has focused in on and to make sure that happens in respect of national strategy. He is correct that the intimidation, coercion and fear are big worries, when people see people dealing on the streets and creating their territory. It is injurious to normal life and the quality of normal life. It creates a fear and tension in communities and there has been violence and aggression. In many ways, it is an informal subjugation of a community. We will talk to the Garda in regard to a tougher line on this. We are constantly increasing the numbers of gardaí. There is already a steady throughput in Templemore that is enhancing our capacity to police in a more visible way on our streets. That is an important dimension to it as well.

On the EU scrutiny committee, I know it has been a lifelong commitment of the Cathaoirleach of the Seanad, Senator Daly. We will discuss that with the respective committees in regard to what is coming before the committee. There are maybe two areas where there is huge and significant simplification going on with legislation at European level. Sometimes we look at all of this as a fait accompli. We are looking at the end of a cycle and maybe we need to look at stuff earlier in the cycle to see if we can make inputs before it becomes a directive and before we are at the legislative transposition stage. Invariably, when that happens, we are up against a clock that is ticking in regard to fines and public servants are saying if we do not get this over, we could risk a fine. There is new agenda now, however, in regard to simplification, and a desire to try and reduce regulation to some degree in various industries and sectors of the economy. Maybe that is something we should intervene early on. There is a reverse way of looking at this.
I thank the Taoiseach.

To conclude, I wish to thank the Taoiseach, his officials and all the committee cathaoirligh. Some 24 people contributed here as cathaoirligh of Oireachtas committees. A huge number of areas were covered and today's engagement highlights the breadth of work of the Oireachtas committees, the members and the staff who work with our committees.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 12.55 p.m. sine die.
